message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acute graft rejection is characterized by a lymphocytic infiltrate with myocyte damage. Granuloma, tissue necrosis, and fibrosis are not typically seen in acute graft rejection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acute graft rejection is characterized by lymphocytic infiltrate, which is the most likely finding on the endomyocardial biopsy. Granuloma and tissue necrosis are more characteristic of chronic rejection, while fibrosis is nonspecific and can be seen in a number of conditions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acute graft rejection is characterized by lymphocytic infiltrate in the graft tissue. Granulomas, tissue necrosis, and fibrosis are not typically indicative of acute graft rejection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acute graft rejection is characterized by a lymphocytic infiltrate, which is seen on endomyocardial biopsy. Granuloma and tissue necrosis are not typically seen in acute graft rejection, and fibrosis may be seen in chronic rejection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acute graft rejection is characterized by lymphocytic infiltrate on biopsy. Granuloma, tissue necrosis, and fibrosis are not specific findings for acute graft rejection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acute graft rejection is characterized by a lymphocytic infiltrate on endomyocardial biopsy. Fibrosis may be seen in chronic rejection, but this question specifies acute rejection. Granuloma and tissue necrosis are not typical findings in cardiac graft rejection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acute graft rejection is characterized by the presence of lymphocytic infiltrate on endomyocardial biopsy. Granuloma may be seen in sarcoidosis, tissue necrosis in myocardial infarction, and fibrosis in chronic diseases such as dilated cardiomyopathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acute graft rejection is characterized by lymphocytic infiltrate, which is the infiltration of lymphocytes into the tissue. Granuloma, tissue necrosis, and fibrosis are not typically seen in acute graft rejection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acute graft rejection is characterized by lymphocytic infiltrate, which is the most likely finding on the endomyocardial biopsy. None of the other options are consistent with acute graft rejection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acute graft rejection is a cellular-mediated process that involves lymphocytic infiltration of the heart. Thus, the most likely finding on the endomyocardial biopsy would be a lymphocytic infiltrate. Granulomas, tissue necrosis, and fibrosis are not specific to acute graft rejection.
